recipe.title: How to Cook Country Style Ribs

procedure.description: Place the 2 tablespoons (25 g) of brown sugar, 2 teaspoons (5 g) of ancho chile, 2 teaspoons (5 g) of chipotle chile, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground cumin, 1/2 teaspoon (1.4 g) of garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon (1.4 g) of onion powder, and 2 tablespoons (36 g) of kosher salt in a small bowl. Stir the spices to combine. You can also use a marinade instead.

procedure.summary: Apply the dry rub to the ribs.
procedure.description: Use your hands to massage the dry rub into the ribs, making sure to get it all over the meat. If you want, you can use latex gloves for this process so you're not coating your hands with seasonings and meat juice.

procedure.summary: Leave the ribs overnight in the fridge.
procedure.description: Place the ribs in a zip-top bag, and put them in the refrigerator for 8 hours. If you're in a hurry, you can cook them after 4 hours instead of 8. Pull the ribs out of the fridge an hour before you want to cook them so they can come to room temperature.

procedure.summary: Heat the grill up to medium high.
procedure.description: Aim for 350 to 450 °F (177 to 232 °C) with your gas or charcoal grill. Let the grill heat up all the way before you cook the ribs.

procedure.summary: Cook both flat sides of the ribs for about 6 minutes on each side.
procedure.description: Start by placing the largest side face down. They should be crusty on that side before you turn them over. Let the other side cook about 6 minutes, too.

procedure.summary: Grill the thin sides of the ribs.
procedure.description: Turn the ribs up on one side, and cook them for another 5 minutes or so. Once that side is crusty, turn them over to the other thin side, and cook that side for 5 minutes. You may need to lean the ribs against each other to grill the thin sides.

procedure.summary: Let the ribs rest for 5 minutes before serving.
procedure.description: Remove the ribs from the grill and cover them with a tent of foil. Letting them rest 5 minutes will help keep the juice in the meat when you cut into it.
